Briony Tallis.Action: Keeps her room meticulously tidy, arranging model animals in orderly pairs.
Typing out her own play with confidence and focus.
Hurries past the housemaid without acknowledging her singing or presence.
Does not glance into the library where others might be, instead focused on her own purpose.
Writes and completes her first play with confident flourish, uses the Oxford English Dictionary as a reference, and keeps her room meticulously tidy and organized.
Hurries down the stairs holding her manuscript, seeming purposeful and focused.
Asks house staff about her mother and announces she finished her play, showing eager engagement.
Ignores cook's request not to get underfoot, indicating disregard for others' work.
Invites Robbie Turner to see her play and offers to let him read it, demonstrating friendliness and openness.
Announces completion of her play confidently to the household staff.
Ignores a polite warning from the cook about being underfoot during busy kitchen preparations.
Successfully initiates contact with Robbie Turner and encourages him to read her play, showing social initiative and goal-oriented behavior.
Demonstrates some social naïveté or inexperience by pressing Robbie to come watch the play despite his hesitation.
Seeks out her mother’s attention persistently and appropriately after Robbie agrees to read her play, showing awareness of social hierarchy and need for approval.
Worries about the rehearsal and considers the feelings of the twins, expressing concern about their ability to act.
Reflects on the difference between writing a story and a play, showing awareness of others’ roles and contributions.
Asks Cecilia why she doesn’t talk to Robbie anymore, showing curiosity about others’ relationships.
Encourages cousins to participate in her play to celebrate her brother's visit.
Responds surprised and hesitant to Lola’s teasing about the play.
Organizes a play and directs reluctant younger cousins, demonstrating initiative and leadership.
Insists the play has to be performed and dismisses the cousins' dislike, showing some forcefulness but not deep understanding of others' feelings.
Agrees reluctantly to let Lola play a part in the school play despite initial hesitation.
Politely but firmly tells Danny Hardman that rehearsals are private and he cannot watch.
Expresses sympathy to Danny when he says he has to work and cannot see the play.
Does not allow others to take an unscheduled break, insisting there is no time for a swim.
Releases the wasp trapped between the window panes.
Accepts Lola’s sudden demand to play the role, showing flexibility and willingness to accommodate others despite personal reluctance.
Takes charge as director, assigning herself the prologue and attempting to keep rehearsals private, demonstrating leadership and control over the situation.
Politely but firmly asks Danny Hardman to leave rehearsal, maintaining boundaries and order.
Rejects suggestion to take a break even though children protest, trying to keep discipline and focus on rehearsal schedule.
Ends up sitting morosely alone, fanning herself and appearing disengaged after Lola leaves, indicating possible frustration or momentary withdrawal from leadership.
Liberates the wasp trapped between window panes instead of killing it.
Gasps and steps back from window when witnessing Cecilia undressing before Robbie.
Notices the wasp trapped between the window panes and deliberately frees it.
Observes Robbie and Cecilia's tense interaction carefully and reacts with a gasp, stepping back in surprise.
Lowers the sash with a bang, accidentally making noise while trying to be unnoticed.
Not present in the excerpt; no direct actions or statements to assess competence.
Sits alone in the shade, intensely focused on writing in her notebook, immersed in her fantasy world.
Sits focused in her special place, furiously scribbling in her notebook, engaged in creative writing with vivid imagination and narrative complexity.
Immersed in a self-created fantasy world involving elaborate characters and plots, possibly indicative of strong literary skill and imaginative capacity.
Takes the envelope from Robbie and runs to deliver it without hesitation or complaint.
Rips open Robbie's private letter impulsively instead of delivering it.
Takes the envelope from Robbie and runs ahead to deliver it without hesitation.
Stops to impulsively open Robbie's letter and reads it, despite it being a private matter.
Thrills Leon with the gift of a play she wrote to perform for him, eagerly sharing her creative work and seeking connection.

Flings herself into Leon’s embrace, showing open affection and friendliness.
Ignores Cecilia’s question and the implied concern, focusing instead on Leon, showing a lack of sensitivity.
Impulsively rips open and reads a private letter without permission.
Successfully writes a play and attempts to share it confidently with family.
Flings herself into an embrace and tries to divert attention by ignoring Cecilia's concern.
Shows obvious sympathy to Lola by noticing her injuries, asking about them, and responding with concern.
Wriggles free from Cecilia’s grip and hurries out of the room, avoiding a conversation about a letter.
Pretends to engage with Leon's conversation to avoid Cecilia; then quickly wriggles free when Cecilia grabs her arm and hurries out of the room.
Paces restlessly in her room trying to make sense of the evening's events, showing active mental engagement.
Notices Lola's bruises and sore wrist, shows sympathy by reaching out and asking detailed questions about the injury.
Initiates a serious conversation with Lola by asking if she can tell her something terrible and preparing her for it.

Warns Lola to keep a secret and expresses concern about what might happen if the secret is revealed.
Gently tells Lola to tidy her face showing a caring, somewhat considerate attitude.

Nods seriously to Lola and tries to respond maturely in a difficult situation.
Asks Lola to promise not to tell anyone, showing awareness of potential consequences.
Picks up the diamond hair-clip in front of the library door and investigates suspicious sounds by cautiously opening the door and stepping inside.
Struggles to find the right mature response to Lola’s blunt comment, indicating limited emotional or social competence at this moment.
Edges closer cautiously to investigate the scene but stops, appearing bewildered and unsure.
Interrupts an intimate moment between Cecilia and Robbie, calling out to Cecilia and entering the room unannounced.
Reluctantly obeys Emily's order to summon the twins for dinner despite mutinous expression.
Discovers a runaway note from the twins and promptly informs the family.
Reads aloud the twins' note explaining their reasons for running away and gives the note to their mother, showing responsibility and concern.
Searches the grounds at night for the missing twins, demonstrating care and active involvement in their wellbeing.

Puts her arm around Lola’s shoulders to comfort her after the assault.
Insists and pressures Lola to identify the attacker as Robbie, despite Lola’s hesitation.
Firmly asserts her accusation against Robbie, presenting herself as protective of her sister.

Rummages through Cecilia’s personal belongings without permission, invading privacy.

Rummages through Cecilia's room and belongings unauthorised, showing initiative but possibly poor judgment.
Opens Cecilia's handbag to find Robbie’s letter, admits she shouldn’t have opened it.
Sits quietly at the piano, suppresses a yawn, does not disturb others.
Obediently follows Emily's sharp order to go to bed despite reluctance.
Awake at night, silently crying into her pillow, showing emotional distress over the situation.
Runs across landing and jumps up to window ledge to watch Robbie being taken away, indicating deep concern and engagement.
Passive observation of events outside without intervening, potentially indicating helplessness or distance.
Cries silently into her pillow, then quickly reacts to the sound of a car starting by jumping out of bed and running to look out the window.
Watches the arrest of Robbie closely but does not intervene or take any action to clarify or change the situation.
Playfully provokes Robbie by asking if he would save her if she fell in the river, then deliberately jumps in, causing him to rescue her.
Disappears into the river unexpectedly, causing alarm.
Engages in risky behavior by jumping into the river and drifting towards the weir, forcing someone else to rescue her.

Looks at her own reflection impassively and says 'There is no Briony.'
Responds respectfully to Sister Drummond's reprimand.

Looks at her own reflection impassively, showing composure and self-awareness.
Performs the mundane task of trimming Fiona's nails carefully and competently.
Retreats quietly and places herself within routine activities (lies back on bed) without resistance or confusion.
Perseveres in writing a story late at night despite distractions and cold surroundings.

Responds to Fiona's personal questions with openness about her feelings and past crush.
Immediately helps carry a stretcher with wounded soldiers despite the physical effort required.
No indication of dismissiveness or selfishness while faced with a chaotic and distressing situation; acts promptly and cooperatively.

Rushes to greet Robbie eagerly but mistakes a stranger for him, showing affectionate and friendly intent.
Works tirelessly in the ward helping wounded soldiers in various ways during chaotic hospital scenes.

Lets the stretcher slip causing pain to the patient and drawing disapproval from the registrar.
Attempts to identify Robbie in a chaotic scene, mistakenly confronts another man but does so with urgency and determination.
Works in the ward helping with injured soldiers by lifting amputees and cleaning wounds, continuing efforts under pressure.

Pulls shrapnel from an airman’s leg firmly and smoothly despite causing him pain.

Swabs oil from a stitched wound and helps lift an amputee back on the bed.
Rips a dressing off a man’s chest, causing him pain and vomiting.

Sits by a heavily bandaged patient, attempts to speak in French with limited skill.

Engages politely with Cornet, asks his name after some hesitation.

Shows sensitivity and empathy by being moved by Cornet's confusion and pain.

Complies silently and obediently with Sister Drummond’s instructions without resistance or evident confidence.
Exhibits a numb, passive demeanor by silently turning away and quietly leaving the ward after being told to wash the blood off her face.

Makes effort to contact Cecilia despite previous silence, showing persistence to reconcile or communicate.
Adapts quickly when the doorbell doesn't work by using the knocker to get attention.
Politely inquires after Cecilia and insists on speaking despite previous lack of response.
Stops and lets the unruly boys pass instead of forcing her way through.

Abruptly launches into her intention without sensitivity to Cecilia's feelings.

Acknowledges the gravity of her wrongdoing and seems aware of the consequences.
Shows uncertainty and hesitance, advances tentatively into the flat and holds onto the table for support.
Plans to tell her parents and explain her change of story after addressing Cecilia first.
Does not seem to fully grasp that reopening the case is unlikely due to her unreliability as a witness, focusing instead on personal absolution.
Admits to having lied and causing Robbie's imprisonment, stands her ground despite his fury, expresses remorse and indicates growth (says 'Growing up').
Admits she did nothing to stop Robbie's imprisonment despite doubts, does not intervene earlier.
Faces Robbie and admits what she did, standing her ground shaken but not afraid.
Fails to understand the consequences of her false accusation when she originally made it at age thirteen.
Shows some growth and awareness by acknowledging her past mistake and recognizing the harm it caused.
Agrees to help undo the false accusation by cooperating fully and correcting her mistake, despite difficulty.
Expresses formal apology for the distress caused.
Initially looks away with shame, showing some internal recognition of wrong, but does not proactively reach out earlier to correct harm.
Promises to comply and leaves with tears in her eyes after a difficult moment.
Turns away from a tender scene and isolates herself, trying not to cry on a busy train.
Interrupts her TV interview, revealing vulnerability by needing a moment to herself and appearing emotional.

Promises to comply ('I will. I promise.') and leaves abruptly, showing a serious commitment to responsibility.
Sits silently on a busy train, attempting to process complex emotions and events, demonstrating introspection and emotional control.
Interrupts her own interview to take a moment for herself, showing self-awareness and recognition of her limits.
Seems overwhelmed emotionally during the interview and later takes aspirin, indicating limits to her ability to manage stress.
Declares her new book will be her last novel calmly, showing control and confidence in her professional decisions.
Admits to being too much of a coward to go and see her sister in June 1940.
Chooses to tell the absolute truth and to be honest in her writing despite the pain it causes.
Calmly contemplates and answers difficult questions about her illness and writing career with honesty and clarity.
Admits to being too much of a coward to face her sister and travel to Balham in 1940.
Works persistently over many years to write and rewrite her novel, seeking the right way to tell her story.
Admits hesitating and not fully committing to truth in her earlier years, indicating internal conflict and avoidance.
Acknowledges her role in preventing her sister and Robbie’s happiness, expressing regret and self-awareness.
Creates a fictional happy ending for Robbie and Cecilia as a 'final act of kindness'.
Reflects on her past actions and deliberately alters the ending of her story to provide a sense of hope and kindness despite it being fictionalized.
